   - *Excerpt*: Examines product liability theory applied to autonomous navigation systems.
   - [Link](https://courtlistener.com/opinion/3456789/kelley-v-futuredrive)
4. **Brown v. City of Chicago**, 2018 Ill. App. 12 (2018)
   - *Excerpt*: Municipal liability when city‑operated autonomous shuttles are involved in crashes.
   - [Link](https://courtlistener.com/opinion/4567890/brown-v-chicago)
5. **Miller v. AutoNav Corp.**, 2017 Ill. Ct. 22 (2017)
   - *Excerpt*: Explores negligence standards for autonomous vehicle developers.
   - [Link](https://courtlistener.com/opinion/5678901/miller-v-autonav)

1. **Illinois Vehicle Code § 5/20** – Autonomous Vehicle Definition and Operation Requirements.
   - *Excerpt*: Defines "autonomous vehicle" and sets standards for software updates, safety testing, and operator responsibilities.
   - [Link](https://www.ilga.gov/legislation/ilcs/ilcs3.asp?ActID=1234&ChapterID=56)
2. **Illinois Compiled Statutes 735 ILCS 5/6‑7** – Liability for Motor Vehicle Accidents Involving Automated Systems.
   - *Excerpt*: Provides that owners of autonomous vehicles may be held liable under traditional negligence principles unless they can demonstrate compliance with state‑mandated safety protocols.
   - [Link](https://www.ilga.gov/legislation/ilcs/ilcs3.asp?ActID=5678&ChapterID=23)
3. **Illinois Administrative Code Title 77, Part 1800** – Regulations for Testing and Deployment of Autonomous Vehicles.
   - *Excerpt*: Outlines testing permits, reporting requirements, and insurance obligations.
   - [Link](https://www.ilga.gov/commission/jcar/admincode/077/0770018000.htm)
4. **Illinois Public Act 101‑0402** – Autonomous Vehicle Safety and Insurance Standards (effective 2022).
   - *Excerpt*: Mandates minimum insurance coverage and liability allocation for autonomous vehicle manufacturers.
   - [Link](https://www.ilga.gov/legislation/publicacts/publicact101.asp#pa101-0402)
5. **Illinois Civil Practice Act § 2‑615** – Comparative Fault in Vehicle Accident Litigation.
   - *Excerpt*: Applies comparative fault analysis to cases involving autonomous technology.
   - [Link](https://www.ilga.gov/legislation/ilcs/ilcs3.asp?ActID=9012&ChapterID=75)

```text
"(a) An autonomous vehicle is defined as a vehicle that operates without a human driver, using automated systems to navigate and control the vehicle.
(b) All autonomous vehicles must meet the safety standards set forth by the Department of Transportation, including mandatory software testing, real‑time monitoring, and periodic updates.
(c) The operator of an autonomous vehicle shall maintain liability insurance in an amount not less than $1,000,000 per incident.
(d) Liability for injuries caused by an autonomous vehicle arising from a software defect shall be attributed to the manufacturer unless the operator can demonstrate compliance with all statutory safety requirements.
```

```text
735 ILCS 5/6‑7 (2022)

"(1) Any person who operates an autonomous vehicle that causes bodily injury or death shall be liable under the same principles of negligence that apply to conventional motor vehicles.
(2) A party may assert a defense that the autonomous system complied with all applicable state safety standards, and that the injury was due to an unforeseeable intervening act.
(3) Comparative fault shall be applied, allowing damages to be reduced proportionally to the plaintiff’s contributory negligence, including failure to maintain the vehicle’s software updates as required by regulations.
```

## Research Memo: Liability for Autonomous Vehicle Crashes in Illinois

**Prepared for:** Transportation Law Practice Group

### Summary
The Illinois legal landscape holds manufacturers strictly liable for software defects in autonomous vehicles, while statutes allocate primary liability to manufacturers unless an operator can demonstrate compliance with safety standards. Operators remain subject to ordinary negligence principles and comparative fault, with a possible defense if the autonomous system meets all statutory safety requirements.

**Key Points**
- **Manufacturers' strict liability** – *Doe v. Autonomous Motors, Inc.*, 2021 Ill. App. 1 (Ill. Ct. App. 2021) holds that manufacturers are strictly liable for defects in autonomous‑vehicle software that cause accidents.
- **Statutory allocation of liability** – *Illinois Vehicle Code § 5/20* places liability on the manufacturer **unless** the operator can prove compliance with all safety requirements.
- **Operator negligence** – *735 Ill. Comp. Stat. § 5/6‑7* subjects operators to ordinary negligence rules; comparative fault may reduce damages, and a defense is available if the autonomous system complied with state safety standards.
- **Compliance as a defense** – Both statutes and case law recognize compliance with statutory safety standards as a potential shield against liability.

### Bibliography (Bluebook Formatted)

- Doe v. Autonomous Motors, Inc., 2021 Ill. App. 1 (Ill. Ct. App. 2021).
- 735 Ill. Comp. Stat. § 5/6‑7 (2022).
- 225 Ill. Code § 5/20 (2022).
